form.definition: noun Y is the 25th letter of the English alphabet.
noun In algebra, y is used as a symbol to represent an unknown value. 4x ;eq 2y.[qr

dictionary.entry:
yachtjOt
noun A yacht is a boat with sails or a motor. It can be used either for sport or for pleasure trips.

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say someone yaks, you mean that they talk a lot in a way that makes you feel impatient. Stop yakking and come and help me put out the washing.

dictionary.entry: yakka`jAk@ noun In informal language, hard yakka means hard work. Shearing sheep is really hard yakka.

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say someone yanks something, you mean that they pull it suddenly and rather roughly. You have to really yank the handle to close the door. He yanked the book out of my hands.
noun In informal language, a yank is an American.
verb If a dog yaps, it barks in a high sharp tone. That little dog is a pestit never stops yapping.
verb In informal language, if you say someone yaps, you mean that they talk loudly in an irritating way. You two kids are really getting on my nervescan't you stop yapping?
noun A yard is a unit of measurement in the old imperial system. It is equal to 36 inches or about 91 centimetres.
noun A yard is a piece of land around a house or building enclosed by a fence. Al's out in the yard playing cricket with his friend.

noun Yarn is thread made from fibres such as wool, nylon, and cotton, and used to make woven or knitted fabrics and garments. I need one more ball of yarn to finish this jumper. This machine spins the wool into yarn.
noun In informal language, a yarn is a long story which may or may not be true. He loved to tell us yarns of his school days. I don't believe it for a minutethat's just one of her yarns.
verb When you yawn, you open your mouth very wide and take a deep breath, usually because you are tired or bored. He was so tired he kept yawning all through the talk.
abbreviation for yard.
adverb In informal language, yeah means yes.

noun A year consists of twelve consecutive months. Each year has 365 days, or 366 if it's a leap year. The calendar year goes from 1 January to 31 December; in Australia the financial year goes from 1 July to 30 June. I'm visiting Europe next year. I've been in Australia for ten years now. My son is ten years old. This time last year was much warmer. The visa is valid for a year.
years noun In informal language, you can use years to mean a very long time. I've known Julia for years. It'll take years to repair the damage.
noun Yeast is a substance which is used in bread to make the dough rise, and in beer to make it ferment.
verb In informal language, if you say someone yells, you mean that they call out loudly. They're a long way awayyou'll have to really yell. We heard a lot of yelling and fighting in the street.
noun Yellow is a colour. The yolks of eggs are yellow.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective yellow verb yellow This old white shirt has yellowed.

form.definition: verb If a dog yelps, it makes a sudden short sharp bark.
verb If someone yelps, they suddenly cry out, usually because they are in pain or frightened. He yelped as I stepped back onto his foot.

noun In informal language, if you say you have a yen to do something, you mean that you have a strong but vague desire to do it. You very much hope to do it one day. I've always had a yen to visit America.
noun The yen is a unit of money in Japan.
adverb You say yes to show agreement or consent. 'Are you ready?' 'Yes.' 'Would you like a drink?' 'Yes, please.' 'Shall I go first?' 'Yes, OK.'
adverb You use yes in response to a negative statement to contradict it, and state that something is indeed true. 'It's not my fault.' 'Yes, it is.' 'This won't take long.' 'Yes, it will.'
adverb Yesterday is the day before today. If it is Monday today, then yesterday was Sunday. He left Australia yesterday. She rang about this time yesterday. We arrived the day before yesterday.
adverb If something hasn't happened yet, it hasn't happened up to now, but it may do so in future. 'What did he say?' 'I haven't asked him yet.'
adverb If something shouldn't be done yet, it is too early to do it now. It should be done later. Don't take the cake out of the oven yetwait another five minutes or so.

adverb You can use yet with comparative forms to emphasise them. Roger is taller than Philip, but Brendan is taller yet. Prices are likely to rise yet higher. The decision has caused yet more controversy.
conjunction In rather formal language, yet can be used to point out a contrast. He has been a very bad father, yet his children still love him.
verb If an area of land yields a certain quantity of crops, this is the amount that can be grown on it. These coastal plains yield twice as much wheat as the land in inland Australia.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone yields something, you mean they give it up to someone who is trying to take it away from them. He refused to yield his weapon.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you yield to someone, you mean that you give in to them and do what they want. Eventually she yielded to her parents and agreed to the marriage. The chairman was forced to yield to the decision of the board.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun yield The yield can exceed three tonnes per hectare.

form.definition: noun Yoga is a type of physical exercise that involves deep breathing and meditation. It is designed to help you relax.
noun Yoghurt is a thick liquid food made from milk which has been curdled by bacteria.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this word is yogurt.

form.definition: noun The yolk of an egg is the yellow part in the middle.

noun In informal language, yonks means a long time. Sandy knows everything about the companyshe's been working here for yonks. It took us yonks to get the computer properly set up, but eventually we did.

pronoun You is used to refer to the person or people one is addressing in speech or writing. Hello, how are you? You must complete the attached form. Are you all coming? I love you. May I have a word with you? Thank you both for all your help.

adjective If someone is young, they have not lived for very long. He's got three young children. She's one of Australia's most talented young artists. It's easier to train dogs when they're young. I snapped off the young branches.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is old.

form.definition: noun The young of animals are their young offspring. The adult lions share the kill with their young.
noun A youngster is a child or young person. We'll have to get a babysitter for the youngsters. You youngsters enjoy yourselveswe old folk will just sit and watch.

pronoun You use your to show that something belongs or relates to the person you are addressing. Is this your book? May I borrow your pen? I met your brother last week. Have you changed your mind? Be sure to get your application in early.

pronoun You use yours to show that something belongs or relates to the person you are speaking to. I've lost my penmay I borrow yours? My son's a bit older than yours, isn't he? Excuse me, is this umbrella yours?
adverb You can use yours at the end of a letter, before your name, as a fairly informal and friendly close. I look forward to seeing you next week. Yours, Peter.
yours faithfully You use yours faithfully as a formal close to a letter that is addressed to someone you don't know by name. Dear Sir or Madam, ... Yours faithfully, Peter Konovalov.
4 yours sincerely You use yours sincerely as a formal close to a letter that is addressed to someone by name. Dear Mrs Dimitrou, ... Yours sincerely, Peter Konovalov.
pronoun Yourself is the reflexive form of you. Don't swing the club like thatyou'll hit yourself. You ought to be ashamed of yourself. You can claim on behalf of yourself and your dependants.
pronoun Yourself is an emphatic form of you. Why do you need my help? Surely you can do it yourself. 'Shut up!' 'Shut up yourself!'
noun Youth is the state of being young. It was an accidentthe result of youth and inexperience.
noun Your youth is the period of time when you are young and growing up. I spent much of my youth overseas. In my youth we didn't have all these computers.
noun A youth is a young man, between the ages of about 15 and 25. The youth at the store helped me to the car with my groceries.
noun In rather formal language, the youth of a country are its young people. The youth of Australia are more adaptable than their parents.
abbreviation for year.

interjection In very informal language, if you say yuk, you mean that you think something is very revolting or disgusting. 'We had tripe for dinner last night.' 'Yuk!' Yuk, what's this stuff in the back of the fridge?
noun A yuppie is a young middle class person who earns a lot of money and spends it freely.[fa[xp
